title-group.article-title: Genomewide Association Study of Maximum Habitual Alcohol Intake in >140,000 US European- and African-American Veterans Yields Novel Risk Loci

contrib-group.on-behalf-of: Department of Veterans Affairs Cooperative Studies Program (#575B) and Million Veteran Program

fn.p: All other authors report no biomedical financial interests or potential conflicts of interest.

sec.title: BACKGROUND
sec.p: Habitual alcohol use can be an indicator of alcohol dependence, associated with a wide range of serious health problems.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: We completed a genomewide association study in 126,936 European-American (EUR) and 17,029 African-American (AFR) subjects in the Veterans Affairs Million Veteran Program (MVP) for a quantitative phenotype based on maximum habitual alcohol consumption (“MaxAlc”).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: ADH1B, on chromosome 4, was the lead locus for both populations: for EUR, rs1229984 (p=4.9 × 10−47); for AFR, rs2066702 (p=2.3 × 10−12). In the EUR, we identified three additional genomewide-significant (GWS) MaxAlc loci: on chromosome 17, rs77804065 (p=1.5 × 10−12), at CRHR1 (corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor 1); the protein product of this gene is involved in stress and immune responses; and on chromosomes 8 and 10. EUR and AFR samples were then meta-analyzed; the associated region at CRHR1 increased in significance to 1.02 × 10−13, and we identified two additional genomewide-significant loci, FGF14 (p= 9.86 × 10−9) (chromosome 13), and a locus on chromosome 11. Besides ADH1B, none of the five loci have prior GWS support. Post-GWAS analysis identified genetic correlation to other alcohol-related traits, smoking-related traits, and many others. Replications were observed in UKBiobank data. Genetic correlation between MaxAlc and alcohol dependence was 0.87 (p=4.78 × 10−9). Enrichment for cell types included dopaminergic and GABAergic neurons in midbrain, and pancreatic delta cells.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The present study supports five novel alcohol use risk loci, with particularly strong statistical support for CRHR1. Additionally, we provide novel insight regarding the biology of harmful alcohol use.
